answers: ATR-IR spec [or attenuated total reflection-infrared spectroscopy]
mouth pipetting [accept descriptions like pipetting by mouth; prompt on pipetting]
parts: Samples for this technique were once ground into a mull with a mortar and pestle and some Nujol mineral oil. Nowadays, it is sufficient to place samples for this technique on the zinc selenide crystal of an ATR instrument unaltered.

The patent of plunger-operated devices by Eppendorf means that it is not necessary to pull liquid with a thumb wheel, a bulb, or with this specific method. This method was exceptionally prone to contamination, though one may still find those who swear by it.
Use of the dimethyl form of this element as an alkylating agent has been entirely phased out due to its tendency to kill its users. Pure forms of this liquid metal are similarly dangerous.
Name this Imagist poet of Helen in Egypt, who wrote under a pen name consisting of their initials.

H.D.'s sequel to her autobiographical novel HERmione is titled for this flower. The speaker of a poem titled for this flower says, "All women are not Helen, / I know that, / but have Helen in their hearts."
This other Imagist poet wrote "Asphodel, That Greeny Flower" and described the title object "glazed with rainwater" in "The Red Wheelbarrow."

answers: Bologna, Emilia-Romagna, Italy [accept Giambologna or Bulaggna]
parts: Name this artist, one of few women Vasari chronicled in his Lives, though he baselessly assumed that her work was inspired by spurned love. She gained notoriety for her extremely intricate scenes carved on fruit pits.

Properzia De' Rossi was born in this city also home to a Mannerist painter who painted a self-portrait playing a clavichord, named Lavinia Fontana. The sculptor of The Flying Mercury added the prefix "Giam" (jom) to the name of this city to form his common name.
De' Rossi carved a version of this scene into a peach pit. Raphael painted this scene for Ludwig Mond, and the Isenheim Altarpiece depicts this scene when closed.

answers: Cato [or Cato's Letters; or the Cato Institute]
parts: Name this person, who worked under the alias Agent 711 in a group headed by Benjamin Tallmadge.

A slave with this name who worked in Washington's spy ring prevented a secret attack during Comte de Rochambeau's arrival to Newport. A series of letters with this name inspired the naming of the largest libertarian think tank in DC.

Tallmadge was a Yale classmate of this earlier spy, who revealed British positions during Washington's retreat from New York City. This spy allegedly said "I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country" before being hanged.

answers: Culann [do not accept or prompt on "Cu Chulainn" or similar answers]
blacksmith [accept similar answers such as metal forger]
Republic of Ireland [accept Northern Ireland, Norlinn Airlan, Tuaisceart Éireann, Eire, or Poblacht na hÉireann]
parts: Name this person. After Conchobar arrives at the party he forgets that he has invited his nephew to this person's house, leading to the destruction of his most famous possession.
Culann (koo-lahn), whose hound gave Cú Chulainn (koo koo-lahn) his name, had this profession. Other people of this profession in mythology included the Persian Kaveh and the Germanic Wayland.
Cu Chulainn was a prominent figure in the mythology of this island nation. This island nation was the setting of the Ulster Cycle.

answers: botanical gardens [accept the Pamplemousses Botanical Gardens; accept the Royal Botanical Gardens, Kew; or Kew Gardens]
parts: Name this island home to an "underwater waterfall" illusion near its mountain of Le Morne Brabant. The term "post office" was first popularized by a misprint on a pair of orange and red stamps named for this island.
Despite popular belief that they were eaten to extinction by Dutch sailors, these flightless birds native to Mauritius most likely went extinct due to invasive macaques eating their eggs.
Port Louis' neighborhood of Pamplemousses (pam-pluh-moos) is home to the largest example of these locations in the Indian Ocean. Amelia Fawcett manages one of these locations at Kew.
Name this gothi after whose death Iceland plunged into a civil war under his nephew Thordor the Stutter that was ended by the Old Covenant. This man wrote a chronology of Norwegian kings.
Sturluson was the most powerful chieftain of Iceland from 1224-1230 while he was on the "law rock" as the lawspeaker of this oldest national parliament in the world.

Gerald Schöning's 1777 translation of Sturluson's Heimskringla posited the location of this site at L'Anse aux Meadows in Newfoundland. Leif Ericson allegedly settled this Viking colony in modern-day Canada.

answers: Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach [or C.P.E. Bach; prompt on Bach]
parts: Name this composer of the A minor keyboard piece "La Caroline" who served as court harpsichordist to Frederick the Great. This composer's piece "Solfeggietto" is often played with just the left hand.

C.P.E. Bach's "Solfeggietto" is an example of a piece in this musical style intended to express "true and natural" feelings. This style made use of appoggiaturas, frequent melodic chromaticism, and sudden contrasts in mood.
C.P.E. Bach was one of the first composers to use this form in his keyboard pieces. This compositional form is made up of exposition, development, and recapitulation.

answers: written in a single sentence [or one sentence; or that there are no periods or one period; prompt on answers about having many clauses separated by commas] (the Ellmann novel is Ducks, Newburyport)
chefs [or cooks] (the Marie NDiaye novel is The Cheffe: A Cook's Novel; the story is Isak Dinesen's "Babette's Feast")
parts: NDiaye's novel Three Strong Women follows three women named Norah, Fanta, and Khady who move between Senegal and this country. That novel won this country's Prix Goncourt, like Simone de Beauvoir's The Mandarins.

NDiaye's early novel Comédie classique shares this unusual formal characteristic with each section of Alain Mabanckou's Broken Glass. Except for interludes about a mountain lioness, a long novel by Lucy Ellmann also has this characteristic.
In a 2016 novel, NDiaye wrote about an unnamed girl who is hired to do this job by the wealthy Clapeau family. In a short story, Martine and Philippa hire Babette to perform this job.

answers: moments of inertia [or inertia tensor; or moment of inertia factor; or mean moment of inertia; or equatorial moment of inertia; or polar moment of inertia; prompt on I; prompt on A; prompt on B; prompt on C]
Darwin [or Charles Darwin; or Charles Galton Darwin]
hydrostatic equilibrium [or hydrostatic balance; or hydrostasy; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name these quantities, which lend their name to a dimensionless "factor" that measures the degree of differentiation of planets. That factor named for these quantities is about 0.33 for the Earth and about 0.07 for the sun.

The moment of inertia factor is commonly approximated using an equation named for Radau and a scientist with this surname. That physicist's grandfather with this surname theorized natural selection after studying Galapagos finches.

The Darwin-Radau approximation assumes the body in question has this property. Dwarf planets must have enough mass to maintain this property, in which gravity and internal pressure cancel out enough for a body to be nearly spherical.

Name this ethnicity, whose literary form was established in the late 1800s in short prose pieces by the Arana brothers. In an epic poem, Ganelon betrays his army in a battle against soldiers of this ethnicity.

Txillardegi (chee-ARK-deg-ee), who wrote the first Basque novel, was much inspired by this Basque-born Spanish-language author of the Generation of '98, whose "nivolas" include Niebla and Abel Sanchez.

The development of Basque literature almost ceased for two decades after this war. In Sartre's 1939 story The Wall, Ramon Gris is accidentally betrayed by Pablo Ibbieta during this war, and ends up shot by Nationalists.

answers: quantum harmonic oscillator [or QHO; prompt on partial answers; do not prompt on or accept "simple harmonic oscillator" or "SHO"]
creation and annihilation operators [accept raising operator in place of creation and lowering operator in place of annihilation; accept ladder operators]
parts: Name this quantum mechanical system whose solutions are proportional to products of Gaussian functions and Hermite polynomials. It is the quantum analogue of a simple classical system used to model springs.

The number operator is the product of these objects, which can be used to find the eigenvalues of a QHO’s Hamiltonian without solving exactly. They are denoted a and a-dagger, and correspond to either adding or removing a quantum of energy from the system.
This other operator is defined in terms of the ladder operators and a complex quantity denoted alpha. This unitary operator generates coherent states.

answers: metanarratives [or grand narratives; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Identify this movement, which is called "the cultural logic of late capitalism" in that book by Frederic Jameson. This intellectual movement emerged as a response to modernity.
Jean-François Lyotard's The Postmodern Condition claims postmodernism is characterized by an "incredulity" to these totalizing stories about historical progress.
A fake quote from Ecclesiastes opens this Jean Baudrillard book, which argues that postmodernity is characterized by a "hyperreality" in which signs have no referents.

answers: Nowruz [or Persian New Year; or Iranian New Year; prompt on New Year]
cleaning one's house [or spring cleaning; accept sweeping; accept obvious equivalents like decluttering]
Shia Islam [or Shi'ism; accept Twelver Shia or Imamiyyah]
parts: Name this holiday that originally joined 6 Gahambar (gah-huhm-buhr) feasts on a religious calendar. On the eve of this day, a family will huddle around a Haft-Sin, on which 7 foods that start with the letter S are laid.

Families will perform this general action in the "shaking the house" ceremony that precedes the Persian New Year. This action should be done the day before Chinese New Year to create space for good luck, but not on the day itself.
Nowruz is celebrated by this branch of Islam since it coincides with the Event of Ghadir Khumm (gha-deer koom), which is interpreted as Muhammad declaring that Ali would be his successor.

answers: Soviet-Afghan war [or the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this neoconservative Reagan-era Ambassador to the United Nations whose feuds with Alexander Haig over the Falklands War resulted in Haig's resignation.

Condoleezza Rice cited a weak response to this conflict as the reason why Jimmy Carter and the Democrats lost her vote. The CIA trained the mujahideen groups that evolved into the Taliban during this 1980's conflict which involved a coup in Kabul.

This former "Goldwater Girl" broke from the Republicans due to the Vietnam War. She chaired the 1993 task force on National Health Care reform and was investigated for suspect cattle futures trading with Tyson Foods.

Name this character who is adopted by the cannon-obsessed Commodore Hawser Trunnion. This character's journey from scamming the nobles of Bath with magic tracks to Fleet Debtors Prison inspired Charles Dickens's early novels.
The Adventures of Peregrine Pickle was written by this Scottish author. This author penned the picaresque novel The Adventures of Roderick Random after translating Don Quixote to English.
This author argued that George Bernard Shaw's Pygmalion was lifted from Peregrine Pickle. An unrelated Peter Smollett convinced Jonathan Cape to refuse to publish this author's novel Animal Farm.

answers: oil tankers [or crude tankers; or product tankers; accept the Tanker War prompt on less specific answers such as ships]
parts: Name these vehicles. Operation Earnest Will was launched to protect these vehicles from Iranian attacks during a phase of the Iran-Iraq War commonly named for them.

In the Tanker War, Iran mined this strategic waterway to prevent oil tankers from entering and exiting it into the Gulf of Oman. Operation Praying Mantis was focused around denying access to this waterway.
Operation Earnest Will specifically aimed to protect tankers operated by this country. In a later war, this country's oil fields were set on fire during the retreat of invading Iraqi forces.

answers: Middle English [accept Early Middle English or Late Middle English]
parts: The Great Vowel Shift describes phonological changes in this stage of English that immediately followed Old English.

In the Great Vowel Shift, some front vowels underwent this kind of change, in which two contrasting sounds become a single sound. Some examples of them in American English include those named pin-pen and cot-caught.
William Labov identified this vowel shift in American English, which began with speakers raising short A. It has led speakers transitioning to a cot-caught merger in places like Pittsburgh.

answers: inflammation [or the inflammatory response; accept proliferative inflammatory atrophy]
parts: Name this cancer, which may be tested for by measuring its impacted organ's namesake "specific antigen." It and another related disease are tested for with a digital rectal exam.

This system for assessing the stage of prostate cancer assigns a value between 2 and 10 based on patterns observed in biopsy samples. The final grade is the sum of the two most dominant patterns, with the number being doubled if only one pattern is seen.
Prostate cancer may arise when this phenomenon afflicts the prostate, which is termed PIA. This phenomenon is a common immune response in which a target area becomes redder, hotter, and more swollen.

answers: zither [accept specific types of zithers such as a concert zither]
parts: Name this instrument, which also plays at the end of a speech in which a character describes how, in five hundred years of peace, the only thing Switzerland produced was the cuckoo clock.
Anton Karas used only the zither in his score for this Carol Reed film noir, in which the pulp writer Holly Martins investigates the death of his friend Harry Lime, who is actually alive.
This actor delivered the famous "cuckoo clock" speech as Harry Lime in The Third Man. He played the title role in Citizen Kane, a film he also directed.

answers: Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union [accept People's Commissar for Foreign Affairs of the Soviet Union]
medical doctors [accept clear knowledge equivalents such as physicians; accept a medical person; accept the Doctor's Plot]
parts: Name this man, accused by Leon Trotsky of exploiting antisemitism in his Great Purge of the Soviet government.
Maxim Litinov held this role in the Soviet Union under Stalin. His successor in this role lost his job when his wife Polina, who was the head of the Ministry of Light Industry, was arrested.

Stalin falsely accused primarily Jewish members of this profession of attempting to assassinate him towards the end of his life, leading to numerous arrests. Khrushchev acknowledged that those charges against this profession were fabricated in the Secret Speech.
